title: Arrays
subject: Data Structures
theory:
An Array is a collection of items stored at contiguous memory locations. Elements are accessed via an index. 
- Access: O(1).
- Search: O(n).
- Insertion/Deletion: O(n) (shifting needed).

examples.explanation: Direct memory calculation: address = base + index * size.

common_mistakes.correction: Accessing arr[5] in a size-5 array (indices 0-4) causes a crash or undefined behavior.

interview_questions.question: Why is array access O(1)?
interview_questions.answer: Because the memory address of any element can be calculated directly using arithmetic logic: Base + Index * Size.

summary: Arrays are the most fundamental data structure.
